description: From Middle English tappe, from Old English tæppa, from Proto-Germanic *tappô. The verb is from Middle English tappen, from Old English tæppian, from Proto-Germanic *tappōną, from the noun.

entries.meaning: A tapering cylindrical pin or peg used to stop the vent in a cask.
examples: Synonyms: spigot, spile

entries.meaning: A device used to dispense liquids.
examples: Synonyms: faucet, handle, spigot, spout
We don't have bottled water; you'll have to get it from the tap.

entries.meaning: Liquor drawn through a tap; hence, a certain kind or quality of liquor.
examples: a liquor of the same tap

entries.meaning: A place where liquor is drawn for drinking.
examples: Synonyms: taproom, bar

entries.meaning: (mechanics) A device used to cut an internal screw thread. (External screw threads are cut with a die.)
examples: We drilled a hole and then cut the threads with the proper tap to match the valve's thread.

entries.meaning: A connection made to an electrical or fluid conductor without breaking it.
examples: The system was barely keeping pressure due to all of the ill-advised taps along its length.

entries.meaning: An interception of communication by authority.
A device used to listen in secretly on telephone calls. [from 20th c.]
(medicine, informal) A procedure that removes fluid from a body cavity.
examples: Synonym: paracentesis
abdominal tap
pleural tap
spinal tap

entries.meaning: (finance) The situation where a borrowing government authority issues bonds over a period of time, usually at a fixed price, with volumes sold on a particular day dependent on market conditions.
examples: tap issue; a bond tap

verbs.description: tap (third-person singular simple present taps, present participle tapping, simple past and past participle tapped)

entries.meaning: To furnish with taps.
examples: If we tap the maple trees, we can get maple syrup!

entries.meaning: To draw off liquid from a vessel.
examples: He tapped a new barrel of beer.

entries.meaning: To deplete, especially of a liquid via a tap; to tap out.
To exploit.
examples: Businesses are trying to tap the youth market.

entries.meaning: To place a listening or recording device on a telephone or wired connection. [from 19th c.]
examples: They can't tap the phone without a warrant.

entries.meaning: To intercept a communication without authority.
examples: Synonym: eavesdrop
He was known to tap cable television.

entries.meaning: (mechanical) To cut an internal screw thread.
examples: Tap an M3 thread all the way through the hole.

entries.meaning: (card games, board games) To turn or flip a card or playing piece to remind players that it has already been used that turn (by analogy to "tapping," in the sense of drawing on to the point of temporary exhaustion, the resources or abilities represented by the card).
(informal) To cadge, borrow or beg.
examples: I tried to tap a cigarette off him, but he wouldn't give me one.

entries.meaning: (medicine, informal) To drain off fluid by paracentesis.
To advance someone for a post or job, or for membership of a club.
examples: Trump interviewed Mueller for FBI job day before he was tapped for special counsel.

description: From Middle English tappen, teppen, from Old French tapper, taper (“to tap”), of Germanic origin, from Frankish *tappōn, *dabbōn (“to strike”) or from Middle Low German tappen, tapen ("to tap, rap, strike"); both ultimately from Proto-Germanic *dab- (“to strike”), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰAbʰ- (“to beat, strike, stun, be speechless”). Related to German tappen (“to grope, fumble”), Icelandic tappa, tapsa, tæpta (“to tap”). Related to dab.

entries.meaning: A gentle or slight blow; a light rap; a pat.
examples: each of them shakes her Fan at me with a smile , then gives her right-hand woman a tap upon the shoulder

entries.meaning: (dance) Ellipsis of tap dance.
(computing, graphical user interface) The act of touching a touch screen.
examples: Coordinate term: click

entries.meaning: A piece of leather fastened upon the bottom of a boot or shoe in repairing or renewing the sole or heel.
examples: Synonym: heeltap

entries.meaning: (military) A signal, by drum or trumpet, for extinguishing all lights in soldiers' quarters and retiring to bed; usually given about a quarter of an hour after tattoo.
(phonetics) A consonant sound made by a single muscle contraction, such as the sound [ɾ] in the standard American English pronunciation of body.
examples: Synonym: flap

entries.meaning: Short for tap of work.

verbs.description: tap (third-person singular simple present taps, present participle tapping, simple past and past participle tapped)

entries.meaning: To strike lightly. [from early 13th c.]
examples: She tapped him on the shoulder to get his attention.

entries.meaning: To touch one's finger, foot, or other body parts on a surface (usually) repeatedly.
examples: Synonyms: hit, patter, pound, rap, strike; see also Thesaurus:hit
He was so nervous he began to tap his fingers on the table.
She tapped her companion on the back to indicate that she was ready to go.
Lydia tapped Jim on the shoulder to get his attention.

entries.meaning: To make a sharp noise.
examples: Synonyms: hit, bang, ping, rap
The tree, swaying in the breeze, began to tap on the window pane.

entries.meaning: (graphical user interface) To operate an electronic device (e.g. a mobile phone) by tapping a specific place on its (capacitive or other) touch screen.
examples: Coordinate term: click

entries.meaning: To designate for some duty or for membership, as in 'a tap on the shoulder'. [from mid-20th c.]
(slang, vulgar, transitive) To have sexual intercourse with.
examples: Synonyms: go to bed with, hit, sleep with, wap; see also Thesaurus:copulate with
I would tap that hot girl over there.
I'd tap that.

entries.meaning: (combat sports) To submit to an opponent by tapping one's hand repeatedly.
examples: Synonym: tap out

entries.meaning: (combat sports, transitive) To force (an opponent) to submit.
examples: Synonym: tap out

entries.meaning: To put a new sole or heel on.
examples: to tap shoes

description: From Persian or Urdu تب‎ (tab, “malarial fever”), ultimately from Sanskrit ताप (tāpa, “fever; heat; pain, torment”).

entries.meaning: An Indian malarial fever.
